awd_titl_txt: Ancient History in the Local Group of Galaxies: The Milky Way's Faintest, Darkest, and Most Ancient Satellite Galaxies
awd_abstract_narration:
The outer region of our home galaxy, the Milky Way, contains a few dozen satellite galaxies.  This is surprising because hundreds are predicted by the prevailing theory of galaxy formation.  The smallest satellite galaxies are also the best places to study the mysterious dark matter.  The team will use cutting-edge observations at optical wavelengths to examine the satellite galaxies.  The observations will help us understand galaxy formation and dark matter.  Senior team members will train junior team members.  The research will be featured in modern exhibits at the historic Mount Wilson Observatory in California.  The exhibits will target elementary and high-school students from underrepresented groups in low-income areas.

The team will obtain spectra and imaging of the recently-enlarged population of candidate satellite galaxies of the Milky Way.  Their goals are to investigate (1) how many satellites are dwarf galaxies, (2) their masses and metallicities, (3) the best targets for indirect detection of dark matter, (4) the differences between dwarf galaxies originating near the Magellanic Clouds versus those formed closer to the Milky Way, (5) their orbits around the Milky Way, and (6) their chemical abundance patterns.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Our Milky Way is surrounded by smaller dwarf galaxies that orbit around it.  The Milky Way's satellite galaxies stand out among the galaxy population in many ways: they are the smallest, oldest, and least chemically-enriched galaxies.  These properties, combined with their nearby location, make them unique probes of the first stages of galaxy formation that occurred in the early universe.  Moreover, dwarf galaxies contain a larger fraction of dark matter relative to ordinary matter than bigger galaxies, providing ideal cosmic laboratories for testing dark matter theories.

From 2005 through 2021, a total of 46 new dwarf galaxies and candidate dwarfs around the Milky Way were discovered.  These galaxies more than quintupled the set of Milky Way satellites that had been identified previously, and extended the dwarf galaxy population by more than a factor of 10 in luminosity, size, and dark matter content.  The primary goal of this project was to characterize as many of the newly-discovered galaxies as possible, so as to understand their history, their production of the chemical elements, and their utility in dark matter experiments.

When this project began, there were 54 confirmed or candidate dwarf galaxies orbiting the Milky Way.  Of that group, stellar velocities were available for 70%, the iron content had been measured for 69%, detailed chemistry patterns were available for 39%, accurate ages had been determined for 33%, and just 19% had published proper motions (the speed at which they move across the sky).

Now, the known population of dwarfs has increased slightly, to 57 systems.  Our knowledge of their properties, however, has greatly improved.  Including a small amount of data that have been collected but not yet published, stellar velocities and iron content are or will  soon be available for 93% of the Milky Way satellites, detailed chemistry will be determined for 56% of the satellite population, space-based ages will be measured for 40%, and 95% of dwarfs will have proper motions.  The remaining objects that have not been studied in detail are largely those that are too faint and/or too distant to observe effectively with current telescopes.

Key results from this work include:

The first spectroscopy ever obtained for at least 11 Milky Way dwarfs and improved spectroscopic measurements for 11 additional dwarfs.  We also obtained the first chemical abundance information for 10 dwarfs.  We used these data to determine the nature, masses, dark matter content, and heavy element content of these systems.

We made the first measurements of the proper motions of the smallest dwarf galaxies.  By combining these measurements with the velocities at which the dwarfs are moving toward or away from the Earth, which we determined using the Doppler shift from our spectroscopy, we computed the orbits of many satellites around the Milky Way for the first time.  We showed that only one dwarf approaches within 20 kiloparsecs (65000 light years) of the Milky Way.  That object, Tucana III, is being torn apart by the tidal forces of the Milky Way, suggesting that other dwarfs on similar orbits may have already been destroyed.  Surprisingly, most of the dwarfs we measured are currently near their closest approach to the Milky Way, which indicates that there may be a substantial number of dwarfs at more distant points in their orbits still awaiting discovery.

We provided the first comprehensive review of the properties and cosmological importance of the faintest dwarf galaxies.

In the ultra-faint dwarf galaxy Tucana II, we detected stars up to 1 kiloparsec (3200 light years) away from the center of the galaxy, which is unprecedented for such a small galaxy.  The distant stars are less chemically enriched than those in the central regions, and may have originated in a collision between two even smaller dwarfs more than 10 billion years ago.  Finding stars so far in the outskirts of the galaxy enabled us to measure its mass at larger radii than has been possible for other ultra-faint dwarfs, confirming that the galaxy's dark matter extends at least to 1 kiloparsec.

Following the discovery of stars with unusually large amounts of heavy elements such as europium and gold in the dwarf galaxy Reticulum II, we examined some of the oldest stars in two larger dwarf galaxies, the Large and Small Magellanic Clouds, as well.  We found that both Magellanic Clouds exhibit unexpected enhancements in the abundance of these elements.  The timescale for producing the heaviest elements therefore must be longer than a few million years, but shorter than 100 million years, providing new limits on the processes that create them.

One postdoctoral researcher and two undergraduate students received training through this project.  Other broader impacts associated with this work included astronomy lessons for elementary school students, lectures presenting research results to the general public, and the development of materials combining history and research for the Mt. Wilson Observatory website.
